formalpara.title: Usage of wildcards
formalpara.para:
The .ext file has a similar syntax to the ADL files, with the support of wildcards:
'*' for any name (component, instance)
'**' for any package name
The annotations are placed where they would be placed in an ADL file, see below.

formalpara.title: Applying the annotations
formalpara.para:
The usage of several .ext files and/or the use of .ext files with other annotations within the ADL files lead to the handling of multiple annotations for a single entity. The Mind compiler handle this situation as follows:
all distinct annotations are appended (ex: @Singleton, @Flatten, @CFlags ...)
in case of several identical annotations with different parameters values (ex: @UseIDL({"myFirstIDL"}) and @UseIDL({"mySecondIDL"})), only one of these annotations is kept. No merge of the parameters values is performed.
Currently, there is no log to inform the user of this conflict.

Enable use of extra debugging information for source code of all primitives (gcc compiler)

note.para: Using this extension enables the debugging information only for the user source code (source files in primitives), whereas enabling the debugging information as a compilation flag to the mindc command line using --c-flags="-g" will enable debugging information also for the code generated by the Mind compiler.

example.title: Enable use of gcov coverage testing tool

note.para: As stated in the , both extension files cannot be used simultaneously to enable extra debugging information ("-g") and coverage testing ("-O0 -fprofile-arcs -ftest-coverage") since they both use the @CFlags annotation, in this case a specific extension file should be used with all flags ("-g -O0 -fprofile-arcs -ftest-coverage").
